results.question: What is the objective of playing the classic version of MONOPOLY?
results.ground_truth:
MONOPOLY 
Property Trading Game from Parker Brothers" 
AGES 8+ 
2 to 8 Players 
Contents: Gameboard, 3 dice, tokens, 32 houses, I2 hotels, Chance 
and Community Chest cards, Title Deed cards, play money and a Banker's tray. Now there's a faster way to play MONOPOLY. Choose to play by 
the classic rules for buying, renting and selling properties or use the 
Speed Die to get into the action faster. If you've never played the classic 
MONOPOLY game, refer to the Classic Rules beginning on the next page. If you already know how to play and want to use the Speed Die, just 
read the section below for the additional Speed Die rules.
results.predicted: The objective of playing the classic version of MONOPOLY game is to become the wealthiest player through buying, renting and selling property. The rules include choosing one token to represent a player while traveling around the board, moving one space, moving two spaces, moving three spaces or move all four spaces, moving between properties with the highest total starting with the Banker, placing their tokens on corner marked "Go," rolling three dice for every turn, only using white dice when determining how much to pay on a utility and not using Speed Die unless landing on the Go to Jail space.

results.predicted:
When using the Speed Die, players can choose to use it for one of three purposes: buying/selling property or houses, collecting rent, or paying fines. When the player uses the Speed Die to buy property or houses, they roll two dice and add up the sum if it is greater than the value of a property or hotel on the corresponding spaces. If the value is less, the player will end their turn as normal.
When using the Speed Die to collect rent, players can either move one space forward or pay the $50 fine shown on the turn card. They cannot use the Speed Die for buying/selling property or houses unless the space they land on has already been sold. If they roll doubles and have not used the Speed Die for a while, they will be subject to Jail if they do not end their turn as normal before rolling again.

a utility. Note: The Bus and Mr.

results.question: What is the process when a player lands on an unowned property and wants to buy it from the Bank?
results.ground_truth:
BUYING PROPERTY: Whenever you land on an unowned property you 
may buy that property from the Bank at its printed price. You receive the 
Title Deed card showing ownership; place it faceup in front of you. If you do not wish to buy the property, the Banker sells it at auction 
to the highest bidder. The buyer pays the Bank the amount of the bid 
in cash and receives the Title Deed card for that property. Any player, 
including the one who declined the option to buy it at the printed 
price, may bid. Bidding may start at any price.
results.predicted: A player landing on an unowned property can buy it from the Bank at its printed price, which they receive the Title Deed card showing ownership. After buying the property, the player may use it as their residence or continue to expand their land by erecting more houses. If you own all properties in a color-group, you may put one house on any one of those unimproved properties provided that they are part of an established color-group with another complete color-group owned by the same player. The owner still collects double rent from an opponent who lands on the unimprived properties of their complete color-group, and you may buy and erect at any time during your turn as long as it's within your possession.

results.question: What advantage does it provide to hold all Title Deed cards of a specific color group together?
results.ground_truth:
PAMNG 
When you land on property owned by another player, 
the owner collects rent from you in accordance with the list printed on 
its Title Deed card. If the property is mortgaged, no rent can be collected. When a 
property is mortgaged, its Title Deed card is placed facedown in front 
of the owner. L 
It is an advantage to hold all the Title Deed cards in a color- 
group (e.g., Boardwalk and Park Place; or Connecticut, Vermont and 
Oriental Avenues) because the owner may then charge double rent 
for unimproved properties in that color-group.

It provides an advantage to have houses or hotel on properties because rent is much higher than for unimproved properties, and it also increases the chances of owning a high-valued property that can be sold at auction to raise funds.

results.question: What happens when a player draws "Get Out of Jail Free" from the deck?

The "Get Out of Jail Free" card is held until used and then returned to

your total worth to the Bank. Your total worth is all your cash on hand, 
printed prices of mortgaged and unmortgaged properties and cost 
price of all buildings you own.

results.ground_truth:
A bankrupt player must immediately retire from the 
game. The last player left in the game wins. MISCEUANEOUS: Money can be loaned to a player only by the Bank 
and then only by mortgaging property. No player may borrow from or 
lend money to another player. L 
We will be happy to hear your questions or comments about this game. Write to: Hasbro 
Games, Consumer Affairs Dept., P.O. Box 200, Pawtucket, RI 02862. Tel: 888-836-7025 
(toll free). Canadian consumers please write to: Hasbro Canada Corporation, 2350 de la 
Province, Longueuil, QC Canada, J4G 1G2.
results.predicted: Yes, there is a way for a bankrupt player to still participate in the game. The BANKRUPTCY rules state that a bankrupt player must immediately turn over all assets to the Bank and withdraw from the game. This means that if you own any property or hotels prior to becoming bankrupt, you can turn them over to the Bank upon your declaration of bankruptcy and then withdraw from the game by handing out proper Title Deed cards.

results.question: What are the distinctive elements of a Monopoly game that are trademarked by Hasbro?
results.ground_truth:
The HASBRO, PARKER BROTHERS, and MONOPOLY names and logos, the distinctive design of 
the gameboard, the four comer squares, the MR. MONOPOLY name and character, and each of the 
distinctive elements of the board and rules are trademarks of Hasbro for its property trading game 
and game equipment. 02004,2007 Hasbro, Pawtucket, RI 02862. All Rights Reserved. TM & @3 denote U.S. Trademarks. 00009-1 
PROOF OF PURCHASE I
results.predicted: The distinctive elements of a Monopoly game that are trademarked by Hasbro include the property trading game from Parker Brothers, which includes the Gameboard, 3 dice, tokens, 32 houses, I2 hotel, Chancellor's and Community Chest cards, Title Deed cards, play money, Banker's traits, and Speed Die. The trademark also covers the classic rules for buyin', rentin', and sellin', as well as the additional rules using a Speed Die.
